newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korea oil firms unaffected by labour unrest.
newsitem.headline: S.Korea oil firms unaffected by labour unrest.

text.p: South Korean oil refiners have been unaffected by the spread of union strikes in protest at a new labour law, industry officials said on Friday.
They said because of the industry's strategic importance to the nation's economy, it has avoided industrial strife in the past and strikes would be unlikely during this round of stoppages.

"The oil industry is too strategically important to the nation," said one official at Yukong Ltd, South Korea's largest oil refiner. "A strike would mean no production and that would deal a big blow to all industries."
Industry officials said considering the impact on the national economy no labour union at an oil firm could easily decide to throw down their tools.
"Workers themselves are not considering such an action because they know how important our industry is to the country's well-being," said the Yukong official.
Moreover, favourable working conditions at the refiners compared with other work places would make them more difficult to head for a strike, industry officials said.

"People working at South Korean refiners are generally happy with the working conditions offered, which includes flexible working hours, better pay and benefits," said a labour relations manager at a local oil company.
"There is no movement towards striking. Things are pretty quiet so far."
Labour strikes were spreading on Friday from important export industries such as automaking and shipbuilding to service sectors such as hospitals and subways.
Unions are protesting the passage of a law which gives employers the right to lay off surplus worker, introduce flexible working hours and replace striking workers.
